title: Phrack Pro-Phile XI: Ax Murderer
historical_context: This article provides insight into the life and views of a notable figure in the hacking and phreaking community during the early 1990s.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture history.
short_summary: This article profiles Ax Murderer, a prominent figure in the phreaking community, detailing his background, interests, and views on hacking ethics. It highlights his contributions to the BBS world and his disdain for destructive hacking.
summary:
In this edition of Phrack Pro-Phile, Crimson Death introduces Ax Murderer, a well-known personality in the BBS and phreaking communities. Ax, whose real name is Mike, began his journey into hacking and phreaking in 1983, influenced by friends and notable figures in the scene. He has been involved with several BBS systems and has a strong preference for phreaking over hacking, although he is also skilled in programming languages such as C, Basic, Pascal, and Machine Language. His interests extend beyond technology to include sports and music, showcasing a well-rounded personality amidst the hacker culture of the time. 

Ax Murderer expresses a strong ethical stance against destructive hacking, criticizing those who compromise systems merely to cause damage. He believes such actions tarnish the reputation of true hackers and phreakers, emphasizing the importance of preserving data integrity. This article not only serves as a personal profile but also reflects the values and community dynamics of the hacking world during the early 1990s, making it a relevant read for those interested in the evolution of hacker ethics and culture.
